caption_original: Last month we participated in “Exercise Salish Sea,” which was the largest largest major incident exercise in Canadian Coast Guard history! The two-day major maritime incident training exercise took place east of Salt Spring Island, British Columbia. Day one focused on search and rescue and involved the evacuation of 100 survivors from a BC Ferry. Canadian Armed Forces Transport and Infrastructure in Canada BC Ferries Royal Canadian Marine Search and Rescue U.S. Coast Guard

caption_original:
Fun Fact Friday:
We are proud to have 114 ships, 23 helos, & 4,500 members working 24/7 to protect & secure the largest coastline in the world.

We are the leading maritime authority in the country, operating 24/7 in some of the most challenging conditions on the earth to provide services that are critical to safety, security and economic growth.

caption_original:
Lieutenant-Commander Dussault joined the Naval Reserve in 1993.  She started her reserve career as a Naval Control of Shipping (NCS) officer, participating in and planning NATO and domestic NCS exercises, and holding various divisional positions at HMCS RADISSON, HMCS DONNACONA, HMCS CARLETON and HMCS CATARAQUI. In 2003, she was appointed Deputy Commander of Naval Cooperation and Guidance for Shipping Unit 2, and then transferred in the same position for Unit 3 to thereafter take command of this unit under Maritime Operational Group 5 in 2007. Since, she re-trained as an Intelligence Officer, has held staff and academic positions at the Toronto Canadian Forces College, and has recently completed a term as Executive Officer of HMCS CARLETON.
 
In 2007-08 she deployed to Kabul, Afghanistan, as the Deputy Commander of the HQ Support Group. During her deployment, she led a support battalion of 400 persons from 40 different countries, looking after the life necessities and security in the NATO Headquarters. During her tour, she completed the rebuilding of an Afghan memorial destroyed by camp construction activity, and led a charity fund raiser for a local orphanage.
 
Her career as a public servant started at Treasury Board Secretariat and Department of Finance. Later, she joined the Department of National Defence, coordinating Army international interoperability programs. Since February 2017 she has joined us as the Manager of Search and Rescue, at the Canadian Coast Guard. 
 
Thank you for your service, Sheyla. 

Veterans Affairs Canada

caption_original:
Today is Navy and Coast Guard Day! On this day, we recognize the important work performed by Canada’s sailors and celebrate Canada as a maritime nation. Three of our Coast Guard colleagues are being recognized for their contributions to maritime safety and security.

Greg Lick is being recognized for his long-standing career achievements and dedicated service to the Coast Guard. Greg joined the CCG in 1985 as an Engineering Officer Cadet at the Canadian Coast Guard College and is now Director General of Ops of the CCG in the NCR! 

Pamela McLaren, an environmental response specialist in the Central and Artic Region, is being recognized for her work during refloat, recovery and spill response missions in the Arctic and Great Lakes. 

Bruce Marsh is being recognized for his consistent demonstration of outstanding leadership in providing Officer Cadets with an exceptional role model. He continually strives to improve Cadets’ Coast Guard College experience by being a coach and mentor. 

Bravo Zulu to all! 

The Navy League of Canada La Ligue navale du Canada

caption_original:
On November 8, 2017, Eric Nickerson received the Nova Scotia Medal of Bravery for his heroic rescue last year. 

The CCGS Spray and the G Peddle SC responded to call off Southwest Nova Scotia. Mr. Nickerson performed an in-the-water rescue of a sailor while transferring from a sinking sailboat.

caption_original:
Eric Arsenault grew up in Quebec City and at the age of 17, enrolled in the Canadian Armed Forces as a Communications Research Operator. 

During his career, he specialized in Languages and Electronic Warfare. He did two six month tours in Alert, NU and a seven month tour in Afghanistan.  After more than 20 years of service, he retired from the Canadian Forces. Later, he joined Public Safety Canada as a Watch Officer. 

Eric now works for Coast Guard as a National Project Manager for the Oceans Protection Plan to strengthen the National Marine Communications and Traffic Services Radar Network. 

Thank you for your service, Eric.

Veterans Affairs Canada

caption_original: We are currently doing the fall markup on the St. Lawrence River. We remove summer buoys and replace some with winter buoys. Since buoys are installed at the safe limits of the channels the marking is a risky operation. It is necessary to maneuver the ship in all kinds of conditions, while considering the risks incurred by the crew. Especially when the bridge is iced, water is dripping from the buoys and the ship is moving, the safety of the crew must remain a priority.

It is necessary to maneuver the ship in all kinds of conditions, while considering the risks incurred by the crew. Especially when the bridge is iced, water is dripping from the buoys and the ship is moving, the safety of the crew must remain a priority.

caption_original:
Rick Fougère grew up in Shediac, New-Brunswick. In 1991, at the age of 20, he enrolled in the Canadian Armed Forces as an Armoured Crewman. 

During his career, he specialized in light armoured reconnaissance with the Royal Canadian Dragoons until 2016. He completed 4 tours in the former Yugoslavia and retired in 2016. After 25 years of service, he transfered to the Coast Guard and is now working as an Incident Command System Officer. 

Thank you for your service, Rick.

Veterans Affairs Canada

caption_original:
Bravo Zulu to the 2017 recipients of the Canadian Coast Guard Exemplary Service Medal in Fredericton, New Brunswick. 

This honour recognizes employees who have completed at least 20 years of service with the Canadian Coast Guard, and have spent 10 of these years working in a position that involves potential risk. These brave and dedicated employees have demonstrated exemplary service through their industrious attitudes, effective work ethics and admirable conduct throughout their careers.

This honour recognizes employees who have completed at least years of service with the Canadian Coast Guard, and have spent of these years working in a position that involves potential risk. These brave and dedicated employees have demonstrated exemplary service through their industrious attitudes, effective work ethics and admirable conduct throughout their careers.

caption_original:
Our ability to ensure the safety of marine traffic would be nearly impossible without our helicopters. 

Roughly 7 million Canadians live in coastal areas, where many people in smaller communities depend of the oceans' resources and tourism to make a living. In order to protect and serve these Canadians, the Coast Guard must rely on its air transportation services to respond to the challenges of this rugged and harsh environment. Learn more: ow.ly/LwwH30groJe

caption_original:
Did you know, our Marine Communications & Traffic Services ensures reliable 24/7 communication, contributing to the safety of life at sea.

Marine Communications and Traffic Services provide distress and safety call monitoring and coordinate responses, broadcast maritime safety information (weather and navigational warnings), screen vessels entering canadian waters, deliver information and advice to regulate marine traffic movement, and take appropriate action to ensure the safe and efficient movement of vessels in Canadian waters. ow.ly/8g1230gq17a
Library and Archives Canada

caption_original:
Rob Justice joined the Canadian Coast Guard in 2013, following a lengthy career in the Canadian Armed Forces. He enrolled in the Royal Canadian Navy in February 1981. 

Rob served in numerous HMC Ships, in various roles such as Bridge Watch-keeper, Communications Officer, Diving Officer, Air Control Officer, and Combat Officer.  

Rob also served in a number of positions ashore such as Flag Lieutenant to the Commander of the Navy, Fleet Scheduler, Domestic Operations Officer and Deputy Director Operational Test and Evaluation.

After retiring from his last post at the Canadian Joint Operations Command, Rob joined Coast Guard as Manager, Office of Incident Management.  He is responsible for implementing the Incident Command System nationally across Coast Guard.

Thank you for your service, Rob.

Veterans Affairs Canada

Rob served in numerous HMC Ships, in various roles such as Bridge Watch-keeper, Communications Officer, Diving Officer, Air Control Officer, and Combat Officer. Rob also served in a number of positions ashore such as Flag Lieutenant to the Commander of the Navy, Fleet Scheduler, Domestic Operations Officer and Deputy Director Operational Test and Evaluation. After retiring from his last post at the Canadian Joint Operations Command, Rob joined Coast Guard as Manager, Office of Incident Management. He is responsible for implementing the Incident Command System nationally across Coast Guard. Thank you for your service, Rob. Veterans Affairs Canada

caption_original:
Evan Boettger enrolled in the Canadian Armed Forces as a Reservist in 1976 and served until his retirement from the Royal Canadian Navy in 2015. Evan joined the Public Service at National Defence in 1989 but decided to remain an active Reservist. From 1989 until 2015 Evan balanced parallel military and civilian careers, and since his retirement from the military, is now relieved to have only one career to focus on. 

Evan served in numerous Canadian naval ships, in roles such as a Signalman, Bridge Watch-keeper, Navigation Officer, Deck Officer, Operations Officer, and Executive Officer, in addition to short service in ships of United Kingdom and France.  Evan was honoured to command several ships and units including HMC Ships Fort Steele and Porte St. Louis at sea, HMCS Carleton in Ottawa and Port Security Units in Maritime Forces Atlantic. Evan also served in several overseas missions and special assignments outside the Navy including service in Afghanistan, Kosovo, and South Sudan, as well as in Canadian Special Operations Forces Command. 

At National Defence, Evan worked in major shipbuilding and aerospace projects for the Navy and the Air Force. In 2002, Evan joined the Canadian Coast Guard as the Manager of Project Management in Integrated Technical Services. Evan is currently Project Director for two Incident Command System projects, as well as National Project Manager for the 24/7 Regional Operations Centre and National Command Centre Project. 

Thank you for your service, Evan. 

Veterans Affairs Canada

caption_original:
In Newfoundland and Labrador the Canadian Coast Guard has 21 light stations with solar charging arrays and battery banks. Two of these stations have hybrid systems that use both wind and solar charging. The hybrid systems are located at Green Island in Fortune Bay and Puffin Island in Bonavista Bay.

A fully operational hybrid system, at a staffed light station, can save approximately 25,000 litres of fuel per year. By using the power of the sun and the wind, we can save from 4,000 to 8,000 litres of fuel annually at each site because fewer helicopter and vessel visits are required.

The Government of Canada is committed to a clean environment and reduced carbon pollution. By utilizing greener power sources, we can help reduce Canada’s carbon footprint.

A fully operational hybrid system, at a staffed light station, can save approximately ,000 litres of fuel per year. By using the power of the sun and the wind, we can save from ,000 to ,000 litres of fuel annually at each site because fewer helicopter and vessel visits are required. The Government of Canada is committed to a clean environment and reduced carbon pollution. By utilizing greener power sources, we can help reduce Canada’s carbon footprint.

caption_original:
Weeks of planning paid off for the Nunavut Fisheries and Marine Training Consortium, NFMTC, in Iqaluit and the Canadian Coast Guard. Starting with a visit to the NFMTC college by CCGS Henry Larsen’s Commanding Officer Neil MacDonald, it was followed up by two days of shipboard training and information sharing. 
 
On Wednesday, November 8th, the NFMTC Bridge Watch Rating class was enthusiastically welcomed aboard CCGS Henry Larsen by Captain MacDonald and his crew. A total of 14 students and staff were divided into three groups and sent to various work stations onboard the icebreaker. They learned about anchoring operations and how a windlass works. They were briefed on launching lifeboats during rescue operations; and about the safe operation of deck machinery including mooring and towing winches. As well, they learned how to steer a large vessel while underway as they pulled up the anchor and sailed in Frobisher Bay for a few hours. The enthusiastic and supportive crew were also able to describe shipboard life and share their experiences working with the Coast Guard. 
 
Captain Phil Hillier, NFMTC, noted that for many students, being on board a vessel of this size was a first for most and that being able not only see how the ship operates but also to actually have hands-on experience was very important in supplementing what is taught at the marine college. Captain Hillier was confident that this experience will motivate the students to want to further a career in the marine industry.

The enthusiastic and supportive crew were also able to describe shipboard life and share their eeriences working with the Coast Guard. caption_original:
After a mandatory safety briefing, on the ground in Iqaluit, #Arctic, Canadian Coast Guard Helicopter 442 , transported a second group of 11 students and two staff from the Nunavut Fisheries and Marine Training Consortium, #NFMTC, to ship from shore, to participate in a day at sea, aboard CCGS Henry Larsen in Frobisher Bay, on Friday, November 10.
 
Following a schedule similar to the one executed earlier in the week, all NFMTC participants were once again engaged by the proud crew in shipboard operations, hands-on training, introduction to engine room machinery and discussions about life on board the ship. This full day of training also included an opportunity for crew to share a meal with the eager students and staff. Of note, CCGS Henry Larsen’s 1ST Engineer Dan White not only eagerly explained the duties of an engine room officer on watch to the students but also celebrated 35 years of service with Coast Guard that very same day!
 
Captain Peter Richards, NFMTC, expressed in a note to Captain MacDonald afterwards, that the entire class was extremely pleased with the day onboard the ship. He said that the crew did a fantastic job showing the workings of the ship, were informative, engaging and very keen to share their knowledge and experiences. Citing this as an immense learning opportunity, Captain Richards feels this will give the students other career options when considering a future in the marine industry. Bravo Zulu CCGS Henry Larsen! #CCGProud!

caption_original: In collaboration with Transport and Infrastructure in Canada, the Canadian Coast Guard holds bi-annual sessions with key #Arctic stakeholders. These conferences are opportunities for representatives from different levels of government, federal departments, Inuit communities, industry, civil society and academia to exchange information on a wide range of topics relative to marine-related affairs in the Arctic, voice concerns and share perspectives. The “Fall 2017 Arctic Week” meetings were held in Iqaluit, Nunavut, from November 14-16. The number of participants varies from 80 – 150 depending on location. The next bi-annual meeting will take place in May 2018 in Montreal. #OurCoasts
